author: {'steamid': '76561198053788131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1530008212}
review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Detached is the VR-only debut title from indie developers, Anshar Studios.

In Detached you play an isolated astronaut floating in space. I found the introduction slightly hard to follow, but from what I can gather, you and your crew are scavengers exploring an abandoned space station orbiting an unnamed planet. Due to space constraints in your ship you're travelling in a cargo pod that becomes detached from the rest of the ship by a cocky pirate with a bad attitude. You're left to fend for yourself, exploring the disjointed parts of the space station's hub while you try to rendezvous with your ship and crew. All you have at your disposal is your EVA suit.

At least your oxygen and fuel tanks are full, for the moment anyway.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
Detached is played from a first-person perspective. It feels slightly claustrophobic, thanks to the readouts on the protagonist's EVA suit being visible slightly in front of the view. More or less of the suit surrounding the faceplate becomes visible as you look around or rotate the view, too, leaving a relatively convincing impression of being inside it.

The game is made using the Unreal Engine and the developers have done a wonderful job with the setting. Though the game is set in one particular asteroid belt near an unnamed planet, some of the space vistas are beautiful and the game really presents a wonderful portrayal of the area. Asteroids range in size and look big, rocky, and unfriendly. The destroyed space station and debris look fantastic, with some lights still functioning and other areas dark and foreboding. The lighting in general is exceptionally well done and used to great effect.

Non-structural models don't look quite as impressive. There's not enough there to give a good impression of the station's purpose; it seems hard to imagine that people might once have lived there, though I suppose it's possible there have been other scavengers there before you, stripping it bare. I would have liked to have seen a bit more evidence of habitation, in any case. Other effects are okay, but relatively limited and also not as impressive as the environmental graphics. The suit's rather silly power-ups are fairly understated.

There were no graphical slowdowns or other issues running the game on my GTX-1070-based laptop, even in some of the larger areas, and I feel it's worth mentioning that the engine's excellent single-button view recentering functionality makes adjusting your viewpoint and position in the real world a breeze; I wish every VR game had this. 

Music is appropriate and does a good job of building and maintaining tension, while not interfering with the game or stealing your attention. It's well made and sounds quite familiar, but I suspect it's just the space opera style is well chosen. Sound effects are good, though the old sound-traveling-through-a-vacuum thing ruins the suspension of disbelief; my guess is that the developers chose to go for a more exciting game rather than a realistic one in this regard.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Initially, Detached runs you through a tutorial section in which you can familiarise yourself with the basic controls. This is definitely necessary! While you may be familiar with 6-DoF 3D games, I think there's a pretty good chance you haven't come across anything quite like Detached before.

The game offers you a choice of three different control methods: arcade, in which the game auto-steadies you and drains your inertia for you when you're not actively firing any of the thrust or attitude jets on your suit; simulation, in which you control your jets and thus your inertia completely manually, but which lets you hold down two buttons to stop your spin or thrust; and astronaut, in which you control everything manually -- including applying counter thrust in order to stop movement in any dimension. For me, arcade was too unrealistic and astronaut too hard, so I stuck with simulation, which was utterly brilliant.

After the tutorial and between each level you'll see a scripted scene telling the story, but I couldn't really follow it. Though I knew basically what was going on, I didn't really know who was doing what to whom, or why, so in the end I just sort of looked at the nice graphics and waited until I could take control again. It's a bit of a missed opportunity from my point of view, but maybe it makes more sense to some people.

Anyway, you then have to make your way around the destroyed space station performing various tasks to reactivate seemingly unrelated systems, before you move onto the next level, while collecting big devices called NANDs and trying to find fuel and oxygen tanks to refill your EVA suit. Along the way you'll find three power ups for your suit: a boost, a shield, and a missile launcher, all of which recharge with time. There are a handful of levels, some with timed sections and drones that attack on site, but which you don't seem to be able to destroy.

I think Detached is probably the closest I'll ever get to a spacewalk. But while the game's setting and excellent control systems could have made a wonderful EVA simulator game, the developers instead chose to make an action game based on time limits, collection-based 'puzzles', indestructible enemies, and -- just to make it even more frustrating -- automatic checkpoint-based saving. The game all but punishes you for exploring the wonderful environment, and being forced to repeat timed sections (especially when you've inadvertently saved at a checkpoint with low oxygen or fuel) over and over is painful.

As the developers warn you straight out on the Steam store page for Detached, this game is not for anyone with even the slightest hint of susceptibility to VR-induced motion sickness. Given the number of reviews mentioning this, I feel I should say something, too, since I'm using a hacked-together VR rig comprising an Android phone, Google Cardboard headset, and Xbox 360 controller. I'd expect this to be a terrible experience compared to the officially supported HTC Vive and Oculus Rift.

Sure enough, for the first half hour or so of spinning about wildly and trying to understand what I was doing, I felt pretty ill and had to take a break. But once I had the basic movements down, and could control my spins and move and look roughly where I wanted to, the motion sickness faded away to barely a whisper, and I could fully appreciate the zero-gravity environment and excellent movement controls. So don't be afraid! Give it a go; what's the worst that could happen!? (Keep a bucket nearby, though, just in case.)

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
Pros:
+ Great environment
+ Excellent movement
+ Brilliant graphics

Cons:
- Time limits and checkpoints
- Indestructible enemies
- Silly collectibles
- Expensive

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Some aspects of Detached are brilliant: the (realistic?) thrust and attitude rockets that control your movement along, and rotation about, all three dimensions; the wonderful environment; the great graphics with excellent use of lighting and darkness; and the atmospheric music. But other aspects of it all but ruin the experience: the time limits, the checkpoints, the indestructible enemies, and the silly collectibles. The story doesn't make any sense to me, either; I don't really understand what's supposed to have happened or how, or why I'm doing what I'm doing.

So how do I add all that up? I'm not completely sure. It's too expensive at its normal price, but on sale it's not so bad. I've played it for a handful of hours and I don't think I can be bothered finishing it, though I may play every now and then just for a bit of zero-G ballet. And I guess that's the problem: as a game it's not that great, but as an experience it's out of this world.

[h1]Save for Later[/h1]

Note: I played this game using VRidge / Riftcat and an Android phone with Google Cardboard headset.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136421655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 511, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1516787807}
review:
It wasn't easy to get to grips with the immersive and authentic experience that Detached provides, but out here, nothing ever is! (Inside Joke).

Wow...that was an immersive experience! 

Detached really is the most authentic space exploration and survival game I have played.  

The intensity is off the charts!

== Controls & Movement ==

Many have complained about the control mechanics, they shouldn't they are excellent, it's just that they will quite rightly spin your head and your stomach if you're not used to it.

So to explain....

The left controller fires the jets which move you forwards, backwards and up & down.  This is easy to learn and induces zero motion sickness.

The right controller however controls your Pitch and Yaw and this is where people come unstuck.

There are three levels of intensity for the movement; to assist people who don't have solid VR legs.

Arcade (for woosies and children)
Astronaut (for serious players)
Simulation (for hardcore nutcases)

I play on Arcade :-)  

I tried Astronaut but I found it too realistic to be honest, I think anyone in space would take time to adjust to the weightlessness and constant propulsion.

In Arcade mode the constant propulsion is eliminated and this makes a huge difference to your ability to retain your breakfast.

So that‚Äôs the controls explained.

== The Game ==
This is without doubt a proper game; it has single player and multiplayer mode.

The single player mode does a good job of recreating an experience of survival in space, it looks good, the immersion is sublime and the gameplay is realistic.

It's not all fast paced, guns a blazing get it while it's hot gameplay, more of a methodical and space simulation experience.

If you want faster paced experience then Multiplayer can provide that.  There are a combination of none combat MP modes available, requiring you to get from A to B to C before your opponent does.

You do have weapons and sheilds and also you can damage your suit by colliding with debree, not to mention the need to keep tabs on your oxygen levels.  This really is a simulation experience.

== OVERVIEW ==
Overall I think this game is excellent, but very, very demanding on your ability to not lose yourself or your lunch.  

I try and stay away from games like this because I know I will suffer (motion sickness is no joke) but this is a game which encourages me to overcome and master the nausea because it is so good.

The game itself is exceptional and very realistic & only the fear of motion sickness prevents me from playing.  

The arcade movement system helps huge amounts and I am able to play 1 MP game without serious incident (unless I accidentally bang into something and start spinning unexpectedly).

In time I will surely overcome motion sickness issues, but I need to take baby steps.

** WARNING **
Play sat down, I started playing this stood up and I nearly fell over a few times!  Be warned.

== FINAL NOTE ==
This is a tremendous game, a lot of time and effort has gone into this so please read the developers warning before buying & don't refund the second you feel sick.

Warning
This is an extreme VR experience that simulates sudden and dramatic acceleration, freefalling, twisting and rolling. Even with the 90 FPS frame rate, it is not for VR-sensitive players.

review:
Na das ist mal ein Erlebnis. (gespielt mit der HTC Vive)
Nach √ºber einer Stunde habe ich das Gef√ºhl, erst an der Oberfl√§che dieses Spiels gekratzt zu haben. Das mag zum einen an meiner Orientierungslosigkeit liegen, aber auch daran, dass ich einfach immer wieder dazu verleitet wurde, einfach durch den Raum zu schweben und die Aussicht zu genie√üen.
Auf die Story gehe ich nicht weiter ein, da sie auch auf deutsch beschrieben ist. Wir sind halt ein Astronaut in den Weiten des Alls und haben mit so manchen Widrigkeiten zu k√§mpfen. Zu denen auf jeden Fall auch die Schwerelosigkeit geh√∂rt.
Und genau die ist eine der besonderen St√§rken des Spiels. Neben einer ausgezeichneten Grafik ist es besonders die Steuerung in der Schwerelosigkeit, die dieses Spiel auszeichnet. 
An unserem Raumanzug befinden sich Steuerd√ºsen, die wir ersteinmal meistern m√ºssen. Das Tutorial ist definitiv zu empfehlen, da man sonst schnell Radschlagend durchs All abdriftet. Wir k√∂nnen n√§mlich nicht nur munter geradeaus fliegen, sondern auch seitlich und horizontal rotieren. (Also auch Schrauben und Saltos machen) Das ist zum einen eine sehr spa√üige Erfahrung, kann aber f√ºr Leute mit schwachem Magen zu echten Problemen f√ºhren. Dies ist definitiv nur ein Spiel f√ºr erfahrene VR-Nutzer, die keinerlei Probleme mit Motion Sickness haben, die Warnung des Publishers ist wirklich angebracht.
Im Verlauf des Spiels finden wir noch zus√§tzliche Module f√ºr unseren Raumanzug, wie einen Schild, oder Raketen, was uns Zugang zu neuen Bereichen der Raumstation erm√∂glicht. Wenn wir nicht gerade durchs All rotieren oder vor Asteroiden klatschen, versuchen wir unsere Raumstation wieder in Gang zu bringen. Dazu aktivieren wir einen Reaktor, sammeln Energiezellen, aktivieren die Kommunikation uvm. Zus√§tzlich m√ºssen wir darauf achten, dass uns Sauerstoff und Treibstoff nicht ausgehen, oder wir durch unbedachte Flugman√∂ver unseren Anzug zu sehr besch√§digen.
F√ºr mich pers√∂nlich geh√∂rt Detached zu einer Erfahrung, die man mal gemacht haben sollte. Das Gef√ºhl der Schwerelosigkeit kommt einfach sehr gut r√ºber, die Grafik ist gut, es l√§uft super fl√ºssig (1080ti, ss 2.0) und macht auch ohne viel Aktion spa√ü. 
Ich werde das Review bei Zeiten noch durch den MP-Part erg√§nzen, kann aber schon sagen, dass es allein die Singlemission schon wert ist.

developer_response:
Hello bronksy, 

Unfortunately I can't speak French, but I will try share some hint, which can improve you experience with Detached. 
First of all, sorry to hear that Detached gameplay is too intense for you. According to the game description, we aimed at players who expect from VR a bit more extreme moments. For sensitive players we have also prepared several solutions to minimize the extreme feelings in the game. The Eagle Eye View option will be the key, which you will find in the game options. Set the value to higher to limit the field of view at intense moments and thus be immune to motion sickness.

In addition, we recommend playing in the Arcade mode and with the "Soft Collisions" option enabled, which helps to correct the flight path in confined spaces.

I hope you'll try Detached again and the extreme feelings will be minimized :)

Regards,
Jacob

author: {'steamid': '76561197981674708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1515013162}
review:
You see how the trailer mocks best practices of VR game design? For a reason. This game is only for the sturdiest of stomachs. I consider myself somewhat of a VR-veteran, but man.. after about 20 minutes even I get nauseous. If you have that friend who'd like to check out VR, don't let this be their first game. They'll never want to touch another VR game after this one.

Having said that, I do recommend Detached (albeit in small doses). It's definitely something else, and the closest you'll get to being an astronaut. That claustrophobic feeling, the silence of space, the feeling of dread with your fuel and oxygen constantly running low.. It's something to be experienced - If that's your thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991206788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1517235731}
review:
This game is different from my previous experiences in VR. The dynamics as well as the whole core of the game is quite different than Robo Recall or Arizona Sunshine. We don't see hands, we don'tt fight with hundreds of enemies, we don't shoot everything that moves, we don't interact with objects that can be lifted and viewed on each side. And yet the game will let you sweat and deliver unforgettable emotions by reflecting the conditions in open space! 

The state of weightlessness is like a big playground, and the flight near a great piece of rock gives a great impression. With the progress of the campaign, the game is getting more and more challenging until we reach the point where we curse not once. The devs forced the players to face a difficult section, where the task is to pass the chamber inside the spaceship. Little mistake makes us start over again, but after succesfull pass... I felt victorious!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972572144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1592836540}
review:
I have played this game for a couple of hours now, which, in a game advertised as having a single player experience of about 2.5 hours isn't bad, I guess.  I'm not sure where the idea of 2.5 hours came from.  I don't think that I'm very near the end and I've played for more than that in total. You would have to be seriously good to get this game done in 2.5 hours.  Admittedly I ended up saving the game with very little oxygen left and ended up having to start the first level from the beginning, but that's a definite possibility for anyone.

This is a space simulation based on Newtonian physics and with 6-DOF.  The basic premise is that you have ended up in a wreck in space and you need to carry out various tasks to get yourself out of the situation.  These tasks generally involve flying from place to place, gathering fuel and oxygen, and pushing buttons.  This doesn't sound all that exciting but when you add in the 6-DOF and control systems it is a very fun and challenging game.  The game is not big on hand-holding and one of the big things that is slowing me down is trying to figure out what some of the parts of the game want from me.  I found myself at one point screaming "HOW THE FUCK DO I EJECT?" at the game repeatedly until I realised that you press the right trackpad, that's just one example.  Just after that I found myself screaming "WHAT THE FUCK?  THIS IS NOT FUN!"  over and over because it wasn't, it was just stressful, but it was short and I got through it.  You'll know the bit when you see it.

There is quite a bit of talk about how this game has the potential to be quite vomit-inducing and I would say that if you are prone to motion-sickness this is not the game for you.  I have never felt motion sick in VR so the idea that this might be the first to induce it had me buying the game as soon as I saw it.  So far I'm fine.  It is quite dizzying but I haven't felt the urge to blow chunks just yet.  

The controls are interesting.  I am playing on Vive with the controllers and in that setup the left controller controls the thrust vector of the suit irrespective of which direction you are actually facing and the right controller controls roll.  The right hand controller requires you to squeeze the trigger and then rotate your wrist in the direction you want to roll.  This is a very immersive means of control but is pretty hard on the wrist.  Mine is absolutely twanging today.  Combining the controls to guide yourself through the puzzles (some of which are time limited) is very challenging.  I went straight to playing on astronaut mode which I gather is more tricky but I wanted maximum realism.

I have not played this game on multiplayer.  I'm just enjoying the single player experience for the moment.

The graphics in this game are excellent and truly convey the scale of the space environment.  I quite enjoy travelling from one place to another by just putting myself into a random roll and then just drifting and enjoying the view.  The music is find and appropriate for the game.  The sound effects in general are very good.

If you have a strong stomach, like a challenge, and don't mind risking some serious RSI, I would highly recommend buying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025892014', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1534662006}
review:
This title is amazing and really shows what VR is capable of: You feel like a space engineer alone in the vastness of space - trying not to die. 

I recommend you play the game on simulation mode while in a seated position (helps immersion and feeling of weighlessness) and complete the brief tutorial. The first two modes are way too easy and don't give you the feeling of immersion.

You have on your suit:
Directional thrusters (up, down, left, right)
Maneuvering thrusters on your suit (Roll, pitch, yaw)
This provides your avatar with a true 6 degrees  freedom of movement in the vastness of space, and the close quarters of space buiding while performing simple interactions. The level of immersion is unparralled - even seated, you can alsmost fool yourself into feeling weighless.

With this comes the one big (but not too big) con:You will experience brief bouts of motion sickness (seconds a most) - but as in real life, they quickly go away after correcting your motion so you can deal with it in the following manner.

1.  Fortunately you have a good computer in your suit which allows you to brake (grip) either the directional or maneuvering thrusters, so don't freak out and puke, just use your brakes and it will go away
2. Focus your eyes on a stationary point on your hud (fuel guage) while regaining control
3. Close your eyes
4. If desperate, remove the headset, but it will never get to this point unless you are truly in a state of panic which means you have other problems.

Give this a legit chacne. If you let yourself escape into it and don't play for hours on end, this title is amazing

author: {'steamid': '76561197996212738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2635, 'last_played': 1565739041}
review:
Fantastic experience.  The first three or four times I played I really felt like I was gonna chuck, with a headache too. To combat this I started playing sitting down which helped quite a lot, restricted rotation (right-hand) to smaller increments and occasionally closed my eyes during the transition, particularly if the rotation was forwards and down. Finally, when I staretd feeling bad I stopped straight away, instead of trying to push through it (as was my initial response) and left it alone for at least an hour before trying again.

By the time I had played six or seven times the effects began to diminish and now (I still haven't quite finished the campaign) I get no ill effects whatsoever.

I have read a few reviews where people said the sold-off Detached as soon as they started feeling rough. This is a shame as it's a beautifully crafted game with stunning scenery and atmosphere. Also unnecessary since, as I can testify, your body/brain will acclimatize over a relatively brief period.  Even (some) fully trained astronauts do the big space-spit when they first arrive in orbit, so give yourself  a chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055343512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1623268823}
review:
A superbly engrossing experience. There has been a lot of talk in reviews regarding nausea. I  held off from buying Detached for ages until I read one review that essentially said treat it as a space simulation and play with that in mind. I did and I've had a great time in the game. Not once had nausea. I've rocked on my feet with the changes to motion and perspective but not once felt I'll.

I'm not going to go over all the usual pros and cons but I'll just go over a few of the small parts from the experience that makes it so immersive.

My top effect is the helmet. So simple but hard to pull off. The helmet feels exactly as you would expect, roomy yet enclosed, excellent sound muting. However for me the most immersive part is you cannot put your head "through" the helmet. If you try the helmet just moves with. So simple but excellent.

The controls are very well done. It's very easy to spin out of control but also to regain control. It ƒèoes feel as it might in space.

Get the experience and find out what it really might feel like in space.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977690305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1528841479}
review:
Absolutely amazing.  While the game dosn't fully make you feel like you are in zero G because you can still sense yourself standing in gravity, it gets pretty damned close.  It's impossible to not get fully immersed while you are playing and feel like you are actually there, floating around.  Detatched takes the VR experience to the level we all imagine it.  Not only do you feel like you are reaching out and can touch things, it does so floating around...  Which is at least what I imagined the VR experience to be like.

The controls are excellent and easy to understand.  After a little practice it starts to become very second nature navigating with them.  The game play so far and story is progressing nicely with interesting puzzles to solve.  I'm excited to strap the headset on try the game again, and I can't say the same for a lot of VR games.  The fit and finish in the game is on par with what a person expects out of a game nowadays.  So many VR games are so bad, or so short that it really leaves me not wanting to try others.  

Graphics are great, and the screen door effect becomes almost non noticable once you start playing with how they have done the visuals.  Absolutely amazing game, a must have for any VR owner.

A word of caution however!  This game is VERY nausiating.  I don't get motion sickness very easily and this game pushed my limits, I could only muster close to an hour before I needed a break.  Try not to play to the point you puke or you won't want to play again!

author: {'steamid': '76561197966649882', 'num_games_owned': 2002, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1497043387}
review:
[h1] Detached- [i] Feeling small and insignificant in the vastness of space has never felt so good ![/i][/h1]
6 degrees of motion is a term i have heard hurled about a lot, and very rarely is it true or if true very rarely is it good to control, detached uses the motion controllers in a very good way (once you get used to them) allowing you to control your direction and angle very well.
It is also one of the most beautiful games i have seen (we are starting to raise the bar in visual quality for vr games, as developers get more used to the strengths and weaknesses of the system and as the engines they use get better and better)
 
[b]ROOMSCALE / ENVIRONMENT[/b] 
The area you will be spending most of your time in the single player game is very well designed and the first time you go into space you really well feel somewhat small and insignificant against a large open space of ...well space.
Oh man that feeling as you look across at a huge asteroid beside you and see your shadow as it sails across it, tiny in comparison. This game really has got some good environments.
Now roomscale‚Ä¶. You are in your space suit and this is done very well so long as you do not move about too much in your physical room, which let's face it you should not do because there is zero gravity and if you want to keep to realism you would not be able to move, but if you do the suit does try to move with you and sometimes it jolts, i also had to use the re-centre button a lot more then i really should of. I tried the game sat down and found i was looking up way too much to make that comfortable.
So if you are stood and do not move about too much in the real world then it is perfect...if you are a fidgeter then be prepared to put up with the odd minor inconvenience (and minor they are)
 
[b]GRAPHICS[/b] 
Again they are great, even when i managed to get an extremely close look at the textures on an asteroid they looked very clear. The assets used are good too. This is one of the higher tier graphical games (i am noticing that Unreal engine seems to be cable of some really nice visuals these days)
 
[b]PERFORMANCE[/b] 
A mixed bag here, first let us clear up one thing, the performance in terms of framerate is spot on, no problem there (though i did lower the pixel density a little due to recording in HD was causing a tiny judder) 
However i experienced two bugs one major and one critical, a door control failed to appear until i left and returned. And the critical one is related to story progression a couple of hours in. To mention the critical one in detail would be a major spoiler, these are bugs that really should not be in a non early access title, but both have been reported and i am sure the developer will fix them.
*EDIT 10/06/17 The critical bug is actually a product of unintuitive design, where the player believes they should do one thing and are meant to do something somewhat crazy. This while still bad is much less bad then a critical bug (and i am told will be fixed in the next two weeks)
 
[b]INTUITIVENESS[/b] 
There is a little learning curve but once you grasp how the controls work it is actually really intuitive. No complaints here.

[b]MOTION SICKNESS[/b]
Make sure that your options are set low enough for you pc to not be reprojecting frames and you should be fine. The fact you can see your helmet around you gives you something to ground yourself with and the even though you will feel like you are moving (at one point i was close enough to a wall for the chaperone to appear and for a minute i really thought it was stupid of the game to rotate the chaperone wall with the character i felt that much like i was the one moving‚Ä¶.hard to explain). In all honesty though i do seem to have somewhat of an iron stomach when it comes to vr.
 
[b]MULTIPLAYER:[/b]
I was unable to test this properly, it has 1v1 multiplayer and the devs did say they could organise a game with them for me to try it, but i wanted to try it as any normal person picking up the game would‚Ä¶. I could not find a single player. Even with a heads up posted on the forum and a 30 to 40 minute wait (not an exaggeration i really did sit and wait for nearly 40 minutes) there was no one playing, get this for its singleplayer content not the multiplayer.
 
[b]PROS:[/b] 
[list]
[*] The movement system is really well done
[*] The atmosphere and feeling of floating in space of being small in a very large area is perfect.
[*] Freedom to achieve your goals in the order you want to do them in.
[*] Graphics are superb.
[*] In my first test i thought i had only played for 15 or 20 minutes, turns out it was double that, sign of a good game!
[*] The developers engage with their users on the forums, can not tell you how important and major that is.
[*] The few cutscenes for the single player are so good. 
[/list]
 
[b]CONS:[/b] 
[list]
[*] No online community.
[*] It is a tad on the expensive side, worth it for the single player but only just, a lower price point may solve the lack of an online community.
[/list]
 
[b]The first try video:[/b]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rzallYGxsQ
 
[b]VERDICT[/b] 
I have 2 hours invested in the single player already and once the bug that stops me continuing is fixed (and i am sure it will be given the devs commitment to the game) i will play more. This is a breathtaking game visually and atmospherically so hell yes i recommend it‚Ä¶.just do not buy it for the multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072577028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1495954432}
review:
A game with a lot of potential, ruined by a silly arcade game-play (do this in 40 seconds or DIE! Shoot that in 20 seconds or DIE! Oxygen that last minutes and turns the whole thing into a stress-experience rather than an exciting experience. All in all it's designed for kids with some type of attention-disorder (you know; those boys girls hate because they do everything too fast for any enjoyment to arise). There's just no time for any fun in this game. It's all about "Hurry, hurry HURRY!! You slouch" (The game literally calls you a slouch, after you just paid them about 26 US$. Of course it's an in-game joke, but it sets the tone for the whole thing: there's no time to enjoy anything and that makes this game a loser-experience IMO))

If you like that type of 'instant gratification' game, then you might find it perfect.

Graphics are quite good, control is ok (I preferred the mode called "VR thrust" using the Vive controllers. There are other modes but they were too coarse for me to master (total spin-fest with those) with no way to adjust fine-control)

The game also has power-ups (more speed, so you have even less time to enjoy anything), and rockets (cause obviously little kids these days are only happy if they get to blow stuff up), and shields (so you can be invincible like iron-man or batman or whatever super-hero you prefer (cue the silly cartoon in the beginning, which I could have happily lived without), cause just being in a space-suit is obviously not enough)

There's a lot that goes wrong with this game-play (if you're looking for a simulator-type game, which this turns out NOT to be)

There are, however, a lot of potential. But it's wasted unless you're looking for a fast-paced action-game.

Also, story-wise, you don't feel connected to the story at all.
Some event happened, that broke a lot of stuff (Did a colleague do it, or what was 'the finger' all about? I didn't get the meaning of that). Some dude talks to you on the radio, but we don't even know his name.

Everything is just so rushed :(

The music is nice, but since I was too slow in doing things it ended up repeating itself in a noticeable way, so in the end it didn't really work too well. It tried to set an ambience, and it got close at times, but it felt like it was programmed for a pace of game-play much faster than I was playing at (And so it repeated itself. That's what you get for being a slouch apparently)

I'm sorry to be so nasty here, but the video gave me a very different impression than I got from the actual game-play. Not that the video is wrong, what you see is indeed what you get, it just gave me the impression that this was a slow-paced half-way simulator-type game and not an arcade-game on steroids.

The game is well-made technically and ran smooth on the GTX980 I have (on an i7 pc), so kudos to the developers for that. Very smooth running visually.
It also looks good. Lighting and shadows. All that is brilliant.
Sounds are good. A mix between being simulator-worthy and arcadia-fest nonsense, but with no glitches.
So technically this game is very good (The 'drifting' helmet-position annoyed me a lot though, but I'm not sure how the developers can avoid that since the game obviously can't allow the player's free VR-movement to cause his/her head to stick outside the helmet. It's not a big deal, but it did annoy me having to reset the helmet-position every time I had looked around just a little bit. Maybe they discovered what is really a VR-limitation here; the trouble with small confined spaces)

I really wanted to like this game, but rather than bring me fun it brought me frustration.
If you're a simulator-type, I don't think it's for you.
If you're an arcade-type, it could very well be for you.
The game is not at fault, it is what it is, I just thought it was more like a simulator-experience allowing you to set your own pace in the game, but it isn't and it doesn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972025376', 'num_games_owned': 1072, 'num_reviews': 265, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1499019046}
review: This is great if you like space and aren't prone to motion sickness. The motion sickness isn't as bad as Adr1ft, but it could affect some people. Just don't let yourself spin all over the place. There are easy to use brakes for your forward and rotational thrusters. There's an arcade control mode that makes it easier to control, but I prefer the astronaut control mode because you tend to drift and spin more, and I prefer that for realism. There are places where you get launched really fast, and they can be a little frustrating because you may have trouble braking or steering yourself and might end up ramming into a solid object and dying, which sometimes sends you spinning (not good for motion sickness people). When you first leave the space station and enter the void of space, it's an amazing feeling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042062250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1495246013}
review:
This game made me feel super sick!  

It doesn't let you move your head around at all.  If you accidentally move your head outside of the helmet the game  then the game snaps your point of view back to the center of the suit.  This is the most chunder inducing sensation I've ever experienced.  The astronaught on the cover clearly has a spacesuit that gives him enough maneuverability to turn his head and look over his shoulder so why the heck can't I?  Instead I feel like I'm driving a stretcher with misalighned rockets strapped to the bottom.

The movement controls were bad.  The left hand controls your main thrusters and the right hand controls your rotation.  Sounds good on paper, but in game It's very awkward and unreponsive.  I Imagine with enough practice it becomes easy but the game doesn't give you any sort of feedback on how you're rotating.  The difference in movement between tilting down and turning upside down is very slight.

The game does something similar to what no mans sky did with it's flight in that it you have to try pretty hard to crash into anything.  The game will magically push you away from any object that it feels you are too close to.  This doesn't help with the motion sickness one bit.

The visuals are really good but I couldn't really enjoy them.  I didn't get to experience much of the gameplay but what I experienced didn't leave any lasting impressions.

Maybe I'll come back to this game when I have more experience in VR.  But for now this game is not fun for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009762687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1495230548}

author: {'steamid': '76561198052331508', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1523491419}
review:
I don't normally get motion sickness but this game can pull off some of the worst nausea inducing motions out of any game that I've played. I can sit down fine and play games like Elite Dangerous and Star Citizen in VR and not get sick, but this game brings it on quickly. Sitting down in a chair while your character is boosting forwards, moving your head around and doing rotations and angles is dizzying and I imagine that this is what it would be like in actual space.

I find that it helps to have a fan blowing on you and taking deep breaths regularly while closing your eyes (for some reason I hold my breath a lot in this game) helps to curb some of the nausea, but after about 30-40 minutes into the game I had to take a break just to get my equilibrium back. If anyone has the stomach and mind for this game, I definitely recommend it. The gameplay is fun and the atmosphere and music is amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983689849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1495151544}
review:
Review based mostly on multiplayer experience.

https://youtu.be/MSNGlD3GUI0

Detatched is an objective based PvP game that simulates a space suit. There is also a single player campaign but this is focused on the multiplayer PvP. 

Detatched has a few varied forms of locomotion but all are intended to mimic space flight. Sorry guys, no teleportation here. This is a prime example of the rare game that it doesn't make sense in. Not only is it PvP but the whole point of the game is mastering how to maneuver a space suit.

That being said, I felt little motion sickness or discomfort. There is a frame that you will see that is constantly in view. This should minimize most motion sickness. There were also comfort options in addition to a full simulation option. It looks like the devs have tried to make sure both sides are taken care of. If you're very sensitive to motion sickness, sadly you may want to steer clear of this one.

As far as the PvP gameplay goes. This is a game to be played with friends for sure. I don't think I'd enjoy randoms as much as getting together with someone you know and popping this in as a social/party game. The fun, for me at least, is more in trash talking your buddies than playing the game.

There were some issues joining a game and we were forced to join via Steam. This was an early build and I hope they've since fixed that bug but I don't know for sure.

I did find that it was very challenging to accurately fly where you wanted to go but I did feel as though I was significantly better after an hour or so of playing. Skill will play a large part of this game and you'll definitely want to at least do the tutorial and maybe 20-30 minutes of the Single Player campaign before jumping into PvP.

I haven't played through very much of the single player story but it does seem to be high enough quality to justify the $24.99 price tag. 

Also remember that being an Unreal Engine game, it plays much better than it records due to the way UE games mirror to the desktop.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970781302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1640222117}
review:
Well, that was stunning.

The single player map (all I've played thus far) of Detached by Anshar Studios is absolutely gorgeous to look at.
The single player map plays out like a metroid-ish game in that progression is determined by the acquisition of new gear to overcome obstacles. You start off in what looks like a hangar on a space-craft.

*MINOR SPOILER ALERT*
[spoiler]I don't recall whether that first room had windows looking out into space or not, but I suspect it didn't.
If I'm right and it didn't, that was a great design choice because two or three doors in, you feel like you're heading deeper into the ship/installation, when all of a sudden you float through the last door and find yourself in open space. It's a very odd feeling which I enjoyed immensely. It's a mixture of "holy shit that's cool!" and "holy shit I'm floating away from safety!", and it pushes the tension up a notch immediately. That was a very clever move indeed.
[/spoiler]
*SPOILER ENDS*

The only speech in the game is your suit computer keeping you appraised of your current situation. As you perform tasks, gently guided by curiosity more than signposting, the suit computer announces the state of the part of what now looks like a disjointed space station as you enter and exit. She also mentions things like "suit damaged" if you manage to clumsily slam yourself into something (which happens quite frequently). More alarming however is the calmly spoken phrase "oxygen low", which left me nervously checking the oxygen readout on the helmet visor as I darted around looking for a green oxygen canister.

I've mentioned it before but it bears repeating, this game is very pretty. The asteroids look great, the man-made installation segments look neat and shiny, the lighting is spot on with glare from the local star when you turn to face it. It's just a joy to look at.

The controls are basically the same as for ADR1FT (right stick to rotate, left stick for thrust, triggers for vertical thrust and bumpers for roll) and the space-suit handles *really* well.
There's an option to select either an arcade mode of play or a simulation mode. The menu suggests that arcade is an easier choice and simulation is only for those with an "iron stomach". Of course I opted for simulation mode ;)
I didn't suffer any nausea, but if I'm honest I can see how others might. The primary difference between the modes as I understand it is that in arcade mode rotation is damped, while in simulation it is not. This means that in arcade mode, once you stop applying rotational thrust, shortly thereafter your rotation will cease.
In simulation mode, unless you bang into something, releasing the rotation button or stick will stop you rotating any *faster*, but halting the turn requires an opposing thrust. This is why some might find it frustrating (indeed, complaints about the controls abound in the reviews on Steam), or sickness inducing, but I think the developer made the right call by giving the player the option and simply warning that it might cause a reaction.
If I'd known the difference between the modes before selecting, I would still have gone for simulation as I'm fairly used to those mechanics from playing Elite: Dangerous, among other games.

According to Steam, the single player map took me 77 minutes to complete. The eagle eyed among you will have spotted the price of this title, but hopefully you'll also have noticed that the single player portion of this game isn't what the developer was focused on. There's a multi-player side to Detached that looks very intriguing.

I haven't checked it out yet, and there was mention made in the reviews of a potential lack of players, but hopefully I'll get a game in tomorrow night. As far as I can gather, the idea is that two astronauts are stranded in space and for reasons not clear to me yet, only one of them can escape to safety. What plays out is supposed to be a relatively violence-free contest between the two players, each attempting to get to safety while frustrating the progress of the other.

It's a neat idea, and with a bit of luck I'll be reasonably good at it (heaven knows I'm bad enough at the rest of the multi-player line up these days).
On a technical note, it worked right out of the gate with vRidge/Riftcat and a wired 360 pad on Windows 10. No issues whatsoever. It even provides a very welcome camera reset function which you can invoke with the back button on the pad. Impressive compatibility scores on all fronts.

So, as far as the single player is concerned, it's a huge recommendation from me for anyone who fancies floating in (beautifully rendered) space for a while in VR.

Whether or not the multiplayer holds together, I'm already glad I own this title.

Great stuff!

review:
VR | Oculus Rift | GTX 1060 Gameplay footage: (With Commentary)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jRPsPP3MaE4

My Thoughts:
My childhood dreams of being a spaceman have finally come true all thanks to the amazing power of VR and this game. Superb visuals and a brilliant atmosphere make this title stand out from the crowd. For an early access game this is turning out to be something very special indeed.


Game Details:
Detached is a suspenseful interstellar duel that demands tactics and skill to survive. Separated from your unit you must make smart decisions and race to safety in this visceral exploration of deep space. Strap yourself into your spacesuit for thrilling gameplay designed for VR headsets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198164837178', 'num_games_owned': 430, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1533409955}
review:
Wow what a beautiful and immersive game! Here is my first 30 minutes of gameplay in Detached, for the first time:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XnbgNvaBxSc

This is my first Detached gameplay, and I have to say that I¬¥m truly impressed with the graphics, perfect control system with the Vive controllers, the great soundtrack and the whole story mode itself. Its just amazing how beautiful the space looks in Virtual Reality, and you get total immersion and feeling of presence while playing this lovely game.

Graphics is amazing thanks to Unreal Engine, its sharp and I get fully fluid 90fps with my 980Ti and 4790k computer. I also have SuperSampling enabled at 1.4 to get it even more crisp, and the game still dont lose any frames at all (even while recording at the same time.

The story mode seems very intresting, and there is probably many hours of gameplay, tasks and exploration of the beautiful scenery out in space. Full Vive control system is added thanks to latest update and it works just perfect. 

I get no motion sickness whatsoever, and I guess all of you guys can play it without problems, even thou it takes some time to get used to the control scheme and all movements.

The soundtrack and music is incredible, it sounds like a Hollywood space movie, and that really adds to the immersion and sense inside of the virtual reality.

I have yet not testet the Multiplayer mode, but I will, and I may update this review further on with more impressions.

I really recommend this game to everyone - this is a MUST-HAVE game for all HTC Vive owners, and a perfect show-off for your friends and people that experience VR for the first time.

Both thumbs up to the developers - THIS is how space games should look like. Just wow!

review:
The team gave me the opportunity to review and play this game, and all I have to say is AMAZING!!!  Its a Space Exploration game, with survival gameplay mixed into it. I wish there was an endless mode as I wanted to keep exploring without having to worry about resources. The game is BEAUTIFUL! I have not done the PVP aspect yet, but am very excited too. 

The only con i have are the controls. It took a ridiculous amount of time to feel comfortable with them. I've read in the comments many other people speaking about "VR Nausea" and the only time I ever felt that was due to a FPS drop. I believe most users had this issue consistently due to either their GPU not being powerful enough, or tied up doing other tasks (like recording).

I actually did a Livestream of this game on twitch and youtube, and have condensed it into parts. Feel free to check out part 1 here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R_JibBl_8Po

author: {'steamid': '76561198047788865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1495894568}
review:
The game in itself is very good, but because of the terrible controls, the game is hard to tolerate. I did not vomit, and i have a high tolerance for motion sickness, but this brings the entire motion sickness part to a whole new level, and that is because of the terrible controls. Because the controls are trying to be TOO realistic, it is hard maneuver around, which can end up making you spin and turn countless of times to get past that wall, making you feel a little uneasy (again, i have a high tolerance level for motion sickness).

I can recommend this game, but only for those with a strong stomach/high motion sickness tolerance, and those that want to waste time on figuring out the controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965335419', 'num_games_owned': 693, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1506005262}
review:
The 'Best' Suit Based Flight Sim out there in VR right now, the Single Player challenge is exactly that, a 'challenge', your judgement and wits are needed to complete challenging tasks in space, inbetween huge asteroids, and vast open spaces of space. The sense of freedom is fantastic. The control system is on point, it takes precise judgement with that just one more go attitude. 
Mutliplayer sees you collect canisters, picking them up at one point, navigating to a panel to open the exit gate across the other side of the huge openworld space map, then frantically try and get to trhe exit gate by the end of the countdown timer. 
This game just keeps me coming back for more. I love it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010071351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1491839104}
review:
Cotton candy. As a kid, I was always fascinated by how it was made in front of my eyes, a huge pink shape was forming, sweet! I always asked for extra layers of sweetness, even if I knew that those last few bites, I would not really enjoy, due to the fact that I had most likely eaten half a kilogram of sugar by that time. 
But let's cut to the chase, as a kid in 1988 I was, first allowed to ride a roller-coaster. What a memorable day that was! The sun was shining straight at my face. One hand squeezing a stick with a huge ball of cotton candy, the second ball this day! In the other hand was a precious ticket for the wild ride, which I never forgot! The queue was moving at the right speed, leaving enough time for me to shuffle huge chunks of sweetness into my mouth, just before I had to jump into my seat. No one knew what was possibly coming. Neither I, or others that decided on a ride that day, or my stomach.
The first bump of the moving cart, gave me excitement, then chills. I was stupid enough to look at what was below the tracks, small people in the distance were waiving hands and smiling, looney toons were playing on the speakers. Sudden cold sweat hit me, turning into sticky hot moisture on my forehead, seconds after. Deep rattling sounds from somewhere in the cart guts, or possibly my own. Surroundings started to wrap around my head tightly, sounds become deep and scary, time was stretching, till it almost stopped. 
Sudden loss of the ground under my feat, the cart start rushing towards its first loop. My head, legs turned to cotton. Sweet and sour tastes on the tip of my tongue, were the last thing I remembered. Minutes became hours, hours stretched into the days, I had lost any meaning of time at this point. 
Sometime later, reality starts coming back to me in waves, first muffled sounds, then blurred vision. Someone yelling at me, a barking dog, crying kids, sporadic excuses and apologies with my mother voice. It took me a while before I realized why I could not properly speak or breath. The reason was that my face, the seats, the crying kid, and the lady holding the squealing dog on the leach, were all covered in a sticky, sweet and steaming pinkish slime. What a day that was.
Time has passed, seasons change, one after the other, memories fade. I was an adult, until this Friday evening. Deciding to relax after a hectic day at work, all house chores done, supper eaten, the game loaded, waiting for me to start. Mistakes, mistakes, huge mistakes were made this evening.
First spawn, a quick look at the surroundings, riding through the first corridor was smooth and easy. A glimpse of a door in the distance, I try to open it. Floating across the room I suddenly had no realization where the top was or bottom of the room was. Cold sweat was the first sign, somewhere around the force-field barrier, the familiar sweet and sour taste in my mouth, has not gone unnoticed. In the next corridor the camera twisted and moments later my knee started to give up. All my childhood memories from that day past, rushed into my head, you can imagine the rest.
It took me several attempts at the game to overcome my nausea, but oh boy, it was worth it! The game with a VR headset, is a totally different experience from anything I have played before. Nothing has ever felt so real and authentic. Every time I jump into a space suit, my hands are subconsciously trying to grab something nearby. Graphics are adequate but scope for improvement.
I will come back to this game again and again, but next time I will not eat before playing, but I still bring the bucket.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962380352', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1495318166}
review:
Wow, finally I can mine in Space! 
It really looks like the real thing that NASA have kept a secret for so long, however the developers NEEDS to add Vive Controller support for this game. Sitting in front of the keyboard gets a bit lame when you see the full potential this game has.
Also, you are not able (yet) to set your own keybindings, finding the "B" button usually ends up frantically hitting every key you find over the spacebar while wearing the Vive Headset.

Vive controllers should become the left and right "controller sticks/armrests controllers" that connects to the Thrusterpack of your spacesuit.

Lifting/tilting the Vive Controllers then interacts as the joystick.

I recommend this game if you know where your keys are on the keyboard.
Else you should wait for the Vive Controller support, that would certainly give this game a big 8/10 from me.
